I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In June 2006, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the United Nations Children's Fund 
(UNICEF),1 and the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS)2 agreed to jointly 
develop a regional HIV and AIDS data hub for Asia and the Pacific.3 The data hub is financed 
by ADB under a regional technical assistance (TA) for Fighting HIV/AIDS in Asia and the 
Pacific4 and by the UNICEF East Asia Pacific Regional Office (EAPRO). The regional HIV and 
AIDS data hub was officially launched on World AIDS Day, 1 December 2008.5 
 
2.  By July 2009, the data hub had recorded more than 56,000 hits. The data hub has now 
been functioning for a year and other UNAIDS regions have expressed interest in developing 
similar regional data hubs.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  HIV epidemics vary considerably from country to country, depending on the social, 
cultural,  and  economic  context,  and  continue  to  evolve.  In  Asia,  the  main  drivers  of  the 
epidemic—unprotected  paid  sex,  sharing  of  contaminated  needles  and  syringes,  and 
unprotected sex between men—put those involved in these risky behaviors, as well as their 
spouses and partners, at risk.6 Importantly, epidemiological models show that the characteristics 
of  HIV  epidemics  and  resources  in  Asia  make  it  possible  for  Asia  to  achieve  Millennium 
Development Goal 6, Target 7 by 2015: To have halted and begun to reverse the spread of 
HIV/AIDS. But to achieve this, countries must allocate resources for the most cost-effective 
interventions, targeting groups that are most at risk and, locally, are driving the epidemics. 
 
4.  Like other communicable diseases, HIV does not recognize borders. With improved 
connectivity and enhanced regional cooperation offering new job opportunities, new complex 
patterns  of  internal  and  cross-border  migration  occur,  creating  new  risks  along  transport 
corridors  and  in  cross-border  areas.  Conducting  joint  cross-border  monitoring,  sharing 
evidence-based good practices, and building cooperation among neighbors to respond to the 
threat and fight the spread of HIV and AIDS will benefit everyone: it is a regional public good. 
 
5.  Responding  effectively  and  efficiently  to  local  HIV  epidemics  requires  up-to-date, 
accurate, and quality-assured information. The objective of the regional AIDS data hub is to 
provide strategic information for national program improvement, taking into consideration the 
regional  context  and  what  is  happening  in  neighboring  countries.  The  data  hub  aims  to 
strengthen data collection and analyses on HIV epidemics in the region (national and regional 
analyses), and to facilitate comparison and exchange of information in the region. The data hub 
covers 26 countries of Asia and the Pacific and contains the latest HIV and AIDS statistics and 
internationally accepted standardized indicators for monitoring HIV interventions. The data hub 
helps countries keep track of their epidemics and risk profiles in the regional context. It helps 
them determine which interventions should be prioritized and how to strengthen partnerships

6.  The regional AIDS data hub is managed by a team of experts, located in Bangkok, who 
report to UNICEF EAPRO, under the supervision of a steering committee comprising ADB, 
UNAIDS, and UNICEF representatives. A scientific technical advisory group (STAG), including 
multidisciplinary HIV and AIDS epidemiologists and public health experts, provides technical 
guidance and accredits the process of data collection and analysis. 
 
7.  The joint ADB–UNAIDS–UNICEF project provided the necessary resources to develop 
the  data  hub  and  assess  if  the  provided  services  would  be  appreciated  by  the  intended 
beneficiaries. With the positive initial response, as reflected by the number of hits and informal 
discussions with national AIDS committees, the data hub is proving to be a useful resource for 
planners and decision-makers. However, new financing resources are needed to maintain the 
functioning of the data hub. After discussions, the partners agreed that additional resources 
would be mobilized on a short-term basis to consolidate results achieved from the first phase. 
They also agreed that new options and financing mechanisms will be explored and a plan 
developed to ensure long-term sustainability of the data hub. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  project  will  contribute  to  achieving  Millennium  Development  Goal  6  by  using 
strategic information to develop and implement cost-effective national and regional responses to 
HIV  epidemics.  The  objectives  are  to  (i)  consolidate  results  and  build  on  the  successful 
experiences  and  institutional  structures  established  during  the  first  phase,  and  (ii)  identify 
sustainable and long-term financing mechanisms, and mobilize new funds through appropriate 
advocacy. The outcomes will be (i) a user-friendly regional data hub on HIV and AIDS providing 
strategic information in support of well-defined strategies for targeted and cost-effective regional 
and national interventions, and (ii) sustainable funding mechanisms and partnership strategies 
identified  to  ensure  long-term  sustainability  of  the  data  hub.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The  project  resources  will  be  used  to  consolidate  results  from  the  first  phase  by 
maintaining the team of experts who are managing the regional data hub, collecting data, 
checking their accuracy, and preparing data analyses. The project will continue advocating 
evidence-based planning and allocation of resources, and the benefit of sharing experiences 
within the region. This implies participation in conferences and workshops where the data hub 
concept is explained and demonstrated. Based on the feedback received from the countries and 
the recommendations of the STAG, the data hub team will develop targeted capacity building 
activities for data collection and analyses, both online and through field visits to national AIDS 
committees. With approval of the steering committee, project resources will be used for regional 
and national training workshops and on-the-job supervision and training in data collection and 
analyses, in a regional context.  
 
10.  The composition and role of the STAG will be carefully evaluated and revised as needed. 
A broader representation of beneficiary developing member countries in the STAG will facilitate 
collaboration, minimize political risks, and increase the credibility of the data hub. UNAIDS and

3
UNICEF will proactively market the use of data through their country and regional offices in 
close  partnership  with  the  Asia–Pacific  United  Nations  Regional  Directors’  Team.  Their 
involvement is crucial to ensure coordination with the national strategic planning process and 
identification of regional and national information gaps. 
 
11.  The memorandum of understanding between ADB and UNAIDS endorses support for 
interventions of this nature. ADB and UNICEF are currently finalizing a similar memorandum of 
understanding, which recognizes the data hub as a good practice and a possible area for further 
collaboration. The World Health Organization is also an active partner and participates in the 
STAG meetings. ADB and its partners plan to expand the partnership base that is supporting 
the operations of the data hub. A regional meeting will be organized to discuss the broadening 
of the partnership base, with new potential members such as the Global Fund, United Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP), and the World Bank. 
 
12.  The  project  will  deliver  the  following  outputs:  (i)  high-quality  data  available  and 
accessible to inform national and regional decision-making; (ii) easy access to data to facilitate 
standard  reporting  and  regional  coordination;  (iii)  strengthened  capacity  for  national  and 
regional data collection and analysis; (iv) a data hub that is widely recognized as a source of 
high-quality data helping improve the quality of evidence-based planning and monitoring (as a 
result of marketing and quality of data and analyses); and (v) identified alternatives to ensure 
long-term financing of the data hub. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB from the Regional and Integration Cooperation Fund under the Regional 
Cooperation  and  Integration  Financing  Partnership  Facility.7 UNAIDS  and  UNICEF  have 
committed to mobilize additional resources and ensure that the regional data hub will continue 
beyond the 2011. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The  project  will  be  implemented  from  May  2010  to  April  2012.  The  existing 
implementation  arrangements  for  the  regional  data  hub,  as  developed  under  ADB  TA  for 
Fighting HIV/AIDS in Asia and the Pacific will be maintained. ADB's Poverty Reduction, Gender 
and Social Development Division, Regional and Sustainable Development Department, will be 
the executing agency. The UNICEF EAPRO, in close collaboration with the UNAIDS Regional 
Support Team for Asia and the Pacific, will be the implementing agency. A project steering 
committee  including  ADB,  UNAIDS,  and  UNICEF  representatives,  will  meet  twice  a  year, 
organize the STAG meetings, and provide guidance to the data hub secretariat. 
 
15.  A secretariat consisting of a team of international and local experts has been set up in 
Bangkok  with  UNICEF  assistance.  The  secretariat  is  responsible  for  the  day-to-day 
management of the data hub under the supervision of UNICEF EAPRO, and ensures regular 
consultations with all the steering committee members (ADB, UNAIDS, and UNICEF). The data 
hub secretariat reports to the steering committee.

16.  UNICEF, in consultation with ADB and UNAIDS, recruited the existing team of experts 
(consultants) in accordance with the Letter of Agreement, Article IV signed by ADB and UNDP 
for the first phase. The current team, still under contract with UNICEF, includes (i) a data hub 
manager, (ii) a research marketing and resources mobilization officer, (iii) an administrative 
assistant, and (iv) a research assistant. The terms of reference are in Appendix 2. If new 
consultants need to be recruited, or if the existing consultants' contracts need to be renewed, 
these  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
17.  Disbursement under the project will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook.8 Advance  payment  procedures  for  training,  seminars,  and  conferences  will  be 
adopted  to  allow  timely  implementation  of  activities.  If  appropriate,  an  extension  of  the 
Agreement between ADB and UNDP for the ADB TA for Fighting HIV/AIDS in Asia and the 
Pacific will be considered. 
 
18.  UNICEF, in partnership with ADB and UNAIDS, will continue to ensure quality assurance 
and timely reporting as part of its management role for the data hub secretariat, and submit 
consolidated narrative semiannual progress reports to ADB. The reporting for the first phase 
was considered to be satisfactory and in line with ADB regulations. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Evidence-Based Advocacy for Fighting HIV/AIDS in Asia and the Pacific: Regional HIV/AIDS 
Data Hub, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  To support project implementation, a total of 84 person-months of international and national 
consulting will be provided: 36 person-months of international consultants and 48 person-months 
of national consultants. Two international consultants—a data hub manager (24 person-months) 
and a research marketing-resources mobilization officer (12 person-months)—and two national 
consultants—a research assistant (24 person-months), and an administrative assistant (24 person-
months)—will make up the consulting team. 
 
2.  During the course of the project, each international and national consultant will carry out 
tasks in close consultation with, as well as report to, the project steering committee.  
 
B.  International Consultants 
 
  1.  Data Hub Manager 
 
3.  The data hub manager will guide the direction of the data hub secretariat to ensure team 
integration and quality control through regular meetings with team members and key stakeholders 
of the project steering committee and scientific technical advisory group (STAG). The data hub 
manager, who will report to the project steering committee and liaise with STAG members, will 
assist in analyzing and supervising the management and maintenance of the web-based repository 
of HIV and AIDS data. This includes carrying out analytical, technical, and managerial functions to 
help ensure excellent quality of the data hub products; as well as providing technical guidance to a 
team of research associates and other consultants on a series of highly technical tasks. 
 
4.  The data hub manager will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Oversee the tracking, compilation, and updating of regional and national data on 
prevalence; incidence, and trend of HIV infection; age and gender-disaggregated 
data and socio-demographic and economic profiles; risk behaviors and vulnerability; 
and response to the epidemic and socioeconomic impact with specific reference to 
adolescents, young people aged 10–24 years, and other data of the United Nations 
Children's  Fund’s  interest  areas  such  as  orphans  and  vulnerable  children, 
prevention of mother to child transmission, and pediatric treatment. 
(ii)  Oversee management of an electronic repository of HIV and AIDS data in Asia and 
the Pacific, including the development and maintenance of data collection and data 
entry logs. 
(iii)  Support the preparation of issues alerts on a biannual basis based on propositions 
from STAG members based on current and topical interest to alert policymakers of 
actions needed. 
(iv)  Undertake regional trend analysis, and behavioral, policy, and response analyses 
together with experts engaged on a short-term basis for specific purposes. 
(v)  Monitor and evaluate project deliverables; provide regular updates to the steering 
committee  on  project  implementation  progress;  prepare  financial  and  progress 
reports; and liaise with partners, in particular, the Asian Development Bank and the 
Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS); and support the research 
marketing  and  resources  mobilization  officer  in  looking  for  further  funding 
opportunities for this initiative.

(vi)  Provide and coordinate timely response to queries from stakeholders, including 
STAG members, and ensure that national AIDS programs, academic and research 
agencies,  intergovernmental  bodies  (e.g.,  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations  or  ASEAN,  the  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation  or 
SAARC), United Nations (UN) agencies, donors and funding agencies, civil society, 
the public, and other key stakeholders have access to the data hub and its products. 
(vii)  Oversee technical quality of data hub products: 
 
(a)  supervise the creation and quality of intermediate files for analysis of data, 
and ensure various types of data are organized in DevInfo as the intended 
platform for the web-based data repository; 
(b)  supervise the quality of regional and country galleries and capsules, which 
highlight key trends, response and gaps, socioeconomic impact, and other 
relevant information; and ensure they are based on updated data and that 
the analysis is accurate and relevant to driving policy actions; 
(c)  provide technical oversight in the development of the DevInfo platform, and 
working out protocols and arrangements with the STAG for routine updating 
of  the  website;  which  should  be  an  attractive,  easy-to-use  electronic 
repository for HIV/AIDS data from Asia and the Pacific; 
(d)  liaise with other organizations to ensure that current data, studies, and other 
information is readily shared with the data hub for inclusion on the website; 
and 
(e)  support the development of data access policy: one access for the public 
and  policymakers,  and  password  protected  access  for  researchers, 
epidemiologists,  and  UN  and  Asian  Development  Bank  staff  (data  and 
information that are not yet officially endorsed, or are irregular and sensitive). 
 
(viii)  Provide managerial and technical support to the STAG, including moderating e-
forum discussion, ensuring the e-forum is set up when the web-based service is 
launched, and conducting face-to-face meetings, at least twice a year. 
(ix)  Work  closely  with  other  partners,  and  participate  in  a  regional  forum  for  the 
development or revision of statistical standards for HIV data, and assist countries in 
the region in applying suitable national statistical methodologies and practices.   
 
  2.  Research Marketing–Resources Mobilization Officer 
 
5.  The data research marketing–resources mobilization officer will undertake the following 
tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist in maintaining and improving a regional HIV and AIDS database for Asia and 
the  Pacific  that  supports  the  tracking  of  HIV  indicators  in  five  domains:  HIV 
prevalence, vulnerability and HIV knowledge, risk behaviors, socioeconomic impact 
of the epidemic, and national response.  
(ii)  Supplement this system with special studies of regional and national significance as 
needed.  
(iii)  Assist  in  producing  reports  and  thematic  papers  for  regional  and  national 
dissemination.  
(iv)  Provide support for regional and national data requests.  
(v)  Assist  in  developing,  coordinating,  and  strengthening  the  regional  and  country 
partner's  collaborative  network  (STAG  members,  focal  points,  key  experts)  in

support of collating data for sharing with the data hub and using the data for policy 
and advocacy. 
(vi)  Strengthen  the  data  hub  and  contribute  to  effective  strategic  management  of 
HIV/AIDS data, managing and collating of data and information, as appropriate, to 
promote evidence-based data use, with approximately 70% of the time directed at 
strengthening the data hub, and the remaining 30% to internal activities of the data 
hub, including report writing.  
(vii)  Provide support for the development of the data hub and its various products such 
as HIV country profiles, regional summaries including communications strategy, and 
data quality assurance mechanisms. 
(viii)  Help manage the gathering of relevant data and/or the data analysis for input into e-
alerts, and regional reports on key issues and updates in consultation with the 
countries in the region. 
(ix)  Keep track of who uses the data hub website, to ensure that users' needs are better 
taken into account. 
(x)  In collaboration with cosponsors and other partners, help develop and implement a 
marketing strategy for the data hub, including targeting audiences such as national 
and local government and civil society organizations.  
(xi)  Assist in providing technical advice to other experts from government, civil society, 
academic institutions, and bilateral and UN agencies on data collection and data 
analysis;  and  broker  technical  assistance  between  experts,  project  managers, 
regional institutions, and the data hub throughout the region. 
(xii)  Facilitate  collaboration  between  the  national  STAG  members,  focal  points,  and 
national monitoring and evaluation group, and the data hub team where needed.  
(xiii)  Explore alternative funding mechanisms to ensure long-term sustainability of the 
data hub. 
(xiv)  Submit a comprehensive report on the various options for new or alternative funding 
mechanisms to the project steering committee. 
(xv)  Produce reports and other information with respect to the HIV and AIDS situation 
and responses, where necessary. 
(xvi)  Carry out other related duties as required by the data hub manager and the HIV 
regional advisor. 
 
C.  National Consultants 
 
  1.  Research Assistant  
 
6.  The research assistant will undertake the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Conduct further investigation of suitable data from journal articles and other sources, 
and ensure that electronic versions and hyperlinks of these are available in the data 
hub website. 
(ii)  Organize codes and reference all the hard copy data sources in the AIDS data hub; 
ensure that all country data, summary sheets, country gallery and capsules for each 
country are available in the country boxes; also, appropriately organize the regional 
and global reference materials. 
(iii)  Assist with the systematic update of the AIDS database, in line with data that has 
recently become available for the 26 countries and Hong Kong, China in Asia and 
the Pacific. 
(iv)  Assist  in  building  national  and  regional  databases  from  the  excel  data  sheets; 
monitor and evaluate the online database and follow-up the process.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(v)  Review and update country review in slides, sets of HIV and AIDS data power point 
presentations,  including  graphs,  prevalence  maps,  and  charts,  utilizing  data 
received and compiled by the regional HIV and AIDS data hub and taking into 
account all recently available sources and other reports and surveillance studies, 
and especially focusing on the indicators for women and children. 
(vi)  Organize all the data hub products, i.e., country data, review in slides, and national 
and regional reviews; and ensure they are updated and accessible for all the team 
members. 
(vii)  Support proofreading of all products of the data hub project, such as the data entry 
sheets, overview in slides, key data issues; and suggestions; and follow up with the 
revisions.  
(viii)  Assist in updating the Evidence to Action website with new products, materials, and 
relevant links. 
(ix)  Provide timely support to the staff of the data hub project and respond to their 
requests for specific data needs such as important meetings. 
 
  2.  Administrative Assistant 
 
7.  The administrative assistant will undertake the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Provide administrative support and handle meeting preparation in relation to the 
data hub project or as assigned by the line manager or regional HIV and AIDS 
adviser. 
(ii)  Update and record details of new and additional reference documents and upload 
them to the website. 
(iii)  Orient  and  train  the  data  hub  team  on  maintaining  the  database  through  a 
systematic  documentation  system  and  in  linking  and  uploading  documentation 
outputs onto the website. 
(iv)  Maintain a system for organizing and cataloging the hard copies of books and 
reports available in the data hub, based on the UN and United Nations Children's 
Fund  library  standard  of  practice  and  ensure  proper  shelves  for  books  and 
periodicals. 
(v)  Perform any other duties as assigned by the line manager or regional HIV and AIDS 
adviser.
